nodes.name: Isaac Newton
nodes.tooltip: Formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation, foundational in classical mechanics. His work in optics and calculus also laid the groundwork for modern physics and mathematics.

nodes.name: Franciscus Sylvius
nodes.tooltip: Physician and anatomist, regarded as one of the founders of modern clinical medicine and chemical pathology. His work on the circulation of the blood and brain anatomy was pioneering.

nodes.name: Martinus Schoock
nodes.tooltip: Dutch scholar and prolific writer known for his work in philosophy, theology, and science. He wrote against René Descartes, contributing to debates on Cartesian philosophy.

nodes.name: John Gough
nodes.tooltip: British mathematician and physicist, blind from infancy, who contributed to the understanding of elasticity and thermodynamics. Mentored John Dalton, influencing atomic theory.

nodes.name: John Cranke
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and philosopher, known for his work in mathematical logic and early contributions to calculus.

nodes.name: Gottfried Möbius
nodes.tooltip: Known for contributions to projective geometry and topology, including the Möbius strip, a non-orientable surface. His work continues to be a cornerstone in mathematical topology and physics.

nodes.name: Johann von Brunn
nodes.tooltip: Mathematician and astronomer, contributed to early studies in geometry and celestial mechanics. His work laid groundwork for modern astronomical calculations.
